p: Wang et al. ( 78) described the outbreak of COVID-19 in the hemodialysis (HD) center of Renmin Hospital, Wuhan University. They identified COVID-19 in 37 individuals among 230 HD patients (16.09%) and 4 individuals among 33 staff (12.12%). They presented mostly mild symptoms, and no one required admission to the ICU. During the observation, 7 HD patients died âˆ’6 with COVID-19 and 1 without- but deaths were not directly related to pneumonia. The causes of death, in fact, were heart failure, hyperkalemia, and cerebrovascular disease (not peer-reviewed) ( 79). In a report of five HD patients, diarrhea was the most common symptom, whereas fever, cough, and dyspnea were not present, thus making the diagnose harder ( 80). In one retrospective multicenter study of 7,154 hemodialyzed patients, about 2% were confirmed having COVID-19 infection and only about 50% of them presented fever while about 20% of patients were asymptomatic ( 81). The mortality rate among these patients is greater than the general population with COVID-19 peaking at about 31% ( 81). The same mortality rate was reported in another retrospective study of 59 dialyzed patients (2 on peritoneal dialysis and 57 on hemodialysis) ( 82).
